case_name: Bhopal Sugar Industries Ltd. v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 491 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 491 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 17, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 226 of 1960.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated January 17, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 226 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 17, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 226 of 1960. Sen and I. N. Shroff, for the appellant. T. Desai, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder 4Narain, for the respondent.

facts.text: The judgment of the Supreme Court was delivered on February 19, 1964 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: February 19, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-Bhopal Sugar Industries Ltd. hereinafter called the Company-was incorporated under the Companies Act of the former Indian State of Bhopal.

facts.text: Bhopal Sugar Industries Ltd. (the Company) was incorporated under the Companies Act of the former Indian State of Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-Bhopal Sugar Industries Ltd. hereinafter called the Company-was incorporated under the Companies Act of the former Indian State of Bhopal. In 1953 the State of Bhopal which was then a Part C State under the Constitution of India enacted The Bhopal State Agricultural Income-tax Act, IX of 1953 providing for imposition and levy of tax on agricultural income.

facts.text: In 1953, the State of Bhopal, a Part C State, enacted the Bhopal State Agricultural Income-tax Act, IX of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In 1953 the State of Bhopal which was then a Part C State under the Constitution of India enacted The Bhopal State Agricultural Income-tax Act, IX of 1953 providing for imposition and levy of tax on agricultural income. The Act was applied to the territory of the entire State of Bhopal and was brought into force on July 15, 1953.

facts.text: The Bhopal State Agricultural Income-tax Act, IX of 1953 was brought into force on July 15, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was applied to the territory of the entire State of Bhopal and was brought into force on July 15, 1953. By the States Reorganisation Act, 1956  No. 67 of 1956 , territory of the Part C State of Bhopal was incorporated with effect from November 1, 1956, into the newly formed State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: By the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 (No. 67 of 1956), territory of the Part C State of Bhopal was incorporated into the State of Madhya Pradesh with effect from November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By the States Reorganisation Act, 1956  No. 67 of 1956 , territory of the Part C State of Bhopal was incorporated with effect from November 1, 1956, into the newly formed State of Madhya Pradesh. Section 119 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, enacted that by the constitution of the reorganized State, no change in the laws in force which immediately before November 1, 1956, extended or applied to any constituent regions, was effected

facts.text: Section 119 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 provided for continuance of laws in force before November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Section 119 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, enacted that by the constitution of the reorganized State, no change in the laws in force which immediately before November 1, 1956, extended or applied to any constituent regions, was effected, and territorial references in the laws to an existing State shall, until otherwise provided by a competent Legislature or other competent authority be construed as meaning, the territories within that State immediately before November 1, 1956.

facts.text: By the Madhya Pradesh Adaptation of Laws (State and Concurrent Subjects) Order, 1956, the Bhopal Act IX of 1953 continued to remain applicable in the territory of the former Bhopal State.

anchor.surface_text: By the Madhya Pradesh Adaptation of Laws  State and Concurrent Subjects  Order, 1956, promulgated by the Government of the State, all laws in force in the regions which were newly incorporated into the reorganised State St,, of Madhya Pradesh were, with certain adaptations and modifications specified in the Order, to remain in force in those areas until altered, repealed or amended, and by that Order the Bhopal Act IX of 1953 continued to remain applicable in the territory of the former Bhopal State, in the new State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: The Legislature of Madhya Pradesh enacted the Madhya Pradesh Extension of Laws Act, 1958, but no alteration was made in the territorial operation of Bhopal Act IX of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Later the Legislature of the Madhya Pradesh State enacted the Madhya Pradesh Extension of Laws Act, 1958, extending several Acts Central as well as State-to the entire territory of the State, but no alteration was made in the territorial operation of Bhopal Act IX of 1953.

facts.text: It is common ground that there was no law providing for levy of tax on agricultural income in the remaining territory of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that in the remaining territory of the State of Madhya Pradesh there was no law providing for levy of tax on agricultural income. The Company paid and continued to pay tax assessed under the Bhopal State Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1953, till some time in 1960.

facts.text: The Company paid and continued to pay tax assessed under the Bhopal State Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1953, till some time in 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Company paid and continued to pay tax assessed under the Bhopal State Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1953, till some time in 1960. On August 4,1960, the Company presented a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur for a writ declaring that Bhopal Act IX of 1953 was unconstitutional and void as being discriminatory

facts.text: On August 4, 1960, the Company presented a petition under Article 226 in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur declaring Bhopal Act IX of 1953 unconstitutional under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: On August 4,1960, the Company presented a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur for a writ declaring that Bhopal Act IX of 1953 was unconstitutional and void as being discriminatory and for appropriate directions, writs or orders restraining the State of Madhya Pradesh from giving effect to the Act.

facts.text: The High Court upheld the Company's plea and issued a writ restraining the State of Madhya Pradesh from enforcing Bhopal Act IX of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the plea of the Company and issued a writ restraining the State of Madhya Pradesh from enforcing the provisions of Bhopal Act IX of 1953, observing that the Act was in clear contravention of the petitioners right under Art. 14 of the Constitution and must be declared void.

facts.text: Authority of the Part C State of Bhopal to enact the Act as originally stood is not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Authority of the Part C State of Bhopal to enact the Act, as it originally stood, is not in dispute, nor are the provisions of s. 119 of the States Reorganisation Act and the Madhya Pradesh Adaptation of Laws  State and Concurrent Subjects  Order, 1956, challenged as incompetent.

facts.text: The plea of infringement of Article 14 is on the ground that agricultural income-tax is levied in former Bhopal territory but not in the rest of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The plea that there is infringement of Art. 14 of the Constitution is advanced on the sole ground that in the reorganized State of Madhya Pradesh formed under the 134-159 S.C.-54 States Reorganisation Act, 1956, agricultural income-tax is ,,levied within the territory of the former State of Bhopal and not in the rest of the territories of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: The Supreme Court set aside the High Court order and remanded the case for retrial.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order and remand the case for retrial to the High Court. The High Court, will, if the Company so desires, give opportunity to the Company to amend its petition so as to adequately plead its case of infringement of the fundamental right to equal protection of the laws supported by necessary particulars.

facts.text: The reorganized State of Madhya Pradesh was formed by combining territories of four different regions.

anchor.surface_text: The reorganized State of Madhya Pradesh was formed by combining territories of four different regions. Shortly after reorganisation, the Governor of the State issued the Madhya Pradesh Adaptation of Laws  State and Concurrent Subjects  Order, 1956

facts.text: The Company claimed that Bhopal Act IX of 1953 deprived residents of the territory of protection under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: It was claimed by the Company that Bhopal Act IX of 1953 deprived the residents of the territory to which it applied, of the protection of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: No affidavit was filed by the State of Madhya Pradesh in reply before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madhya Pradesh did not file any affidavit in reply before the High Court, and chose to defend the petition as if its decision depended on a pure question of law

facts.text: The petition by the Company was deficient in particulars to justify infringement of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The petition filed by the Company was singularly deficient in furnishing particulars which would justify the plea of infringement of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

It was claimed by the Company that Bhopal Act IX of 1953 deprived the residents of the territory to which it applied, of the protection of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether there is infringement of Article 14 of the Constitution by levying agricultural income-tax only in the territory of the former State of Bhopal and not in the rest of the territories of the reorganized State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The plea that there is infringement of Art. 14 of the Constitution is advanced on the sole ground that in the reorganized State of Madhya Pradesh formed under the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, agricultural income-tax is ,,levied within the territory

issues.text: Whether a proper geographical classification bearing a reasonable and just relation to the object sought to be achieved, founded on historical reasons post-states reorganisation, is permissible under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The State is undoubtedly enjoined by Art. 14 of the Constitution number to deny to any person equal protection of the laws within the territory, but a proper classification bearing a reasonable and just relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute does number on that account become impermissible.

issues.text: Whether the passage of time since the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, has obliterated the necessity and expediency justifying the continuance of the Bhopal Act only in the former Bhopal territory, rendering it violative of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: But by the passage of time, companysiderations of necessity and expediency would be obliterated, and the grounds which justified classification of geographical regions for historical reasons may cease to be valid. A purely temporary provision which because of companypelling forces justified differential treatment

issues.text: Whether the petition adequately pleads and provides particulars and evidence to establish denial of equal protection under Article 14, including inquiry into overall tax burden across regions.

anchor.surface_text: The petition filed by the Company was singularly deficient in furnishing particulars which would justify the plea of infringement of Art. 14 of the Constitution. It cannot be too strongly emphasized that to make out a case of denial of the equal protection of the laws under Art. 14

arguments.claim: Bhopal Act IX of 1953 is unconstitutional and void as being discriminatory under Article 14 because it levies agricultural income-tax only in the former Bhopal territory and not in the rest of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: On August 4,1960, the Company presented a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur for a writ declaring that Bhopal Act IX of 1953 was unconstitutional and void as being discriminatory and for appropriate directions, writs or orders restraining the State of Madhya Pradesh from giving effect to the Act. It was claimed by the Company that Bhopal Act IX of 1953 deprived the residents of the territory to which it applied, of the protection of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Acknowledges prima facie differential treatment but requires evidence of unreasonableness and lack of rational basis; remands for trial.

arguments.claim: The Act deprives residents of the Bhopal territory of protection under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: It was claimed by the Company that Bhopal Act IX of 1953 deprived the residents of the territory to which it applied, of the protection of Art. 14 of the Constitution. The High Court upheld the plea of the Company and issued a writ restraining the State of Madhya Pradesh from enforcing the provisions of Bhopal Act IX of 1953, observing that the Act was in clear contravention of the petitioners right under Art. 14 of the Constitution and must be declared void.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: upon this region, without any apparently justifiable ground, an inference of discrimination may arise. In adjudging reasonableness of classification

arguments.court_reasoning: Petition deficient in particulars; no evidence of overall tax burden disparity.

arguments.claim: The Act is in clear contravention of the petitioner's right under Article 14 and must be declared void.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the plea of the Company and issued a writ restraining the State of Madhya Pradesh from enforcing the provisions of Bhopal Act IX of 1953, observing that the Act was in clear contravention of the petitioners right under Art. 14 of the Constitution and must be declared void.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the funda- mental right under Art. 14 of the Constitution. The State also did number place evidence before the High Court, which would in the very nat

arguments.court_reasoning: Set aside due to lack of adequate pleadings and evidence; remanded for retrial.

arguments.claim: There is infringement of Article 14 solely because agricultural income-tax is levied in former Bhopal territory but not in the rest of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The plea that there is infringement of Art. 14 of the Constitution is advanced on the sole ground that in the reorganized State of Madhya Pradesh formed under the 134-159 S.C.-54 States Reorganisation Act, 1956, agricultural income-tax is ,,levied within the territory of the former State of Bhopal and not in the rest of the territories of Madhya Pradesh. Prima facie, a differential treatment is accorded by the State of Madhya Pradesh to persons carrying on agricultural operations in the Bhopal region, because the State subjects them to pay tax on agricultural income, which is not imposed upon agricultural income earned in the rest of the State.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: te, number are the provisions of s. 119 of the States Reorganisation Act and the Madhya Pradesh Adaptation of Laws  State and Concurrent Subjects  Ord

arguments.court_reasoning: Differential treatment alone not sufficient; requires showing of arbitrariness without rational relation to object.

arguments.claim: If the Act was not discriminatory at the time of reorganisation due to historical reasons, it can never become discriminatory thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madhya Pradesh did not file any affidavit in reply before the High Court, and chose to defend the petition as if its decision depended on a pure question of law, that if for historical reasons the Act in operation in a -region incorporated in the new State was not discriminatory at the date when the reorganisation took place, it can never become discriminatory thereafter.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: or the purpose of taxation, the Courts recognise greater freedom in the Legislature and if the statute discloses a permissible policy of taxation, th

arguments.court_reasoning: Assumptions erroneous; passage of time may obliterate necessity and expediency justifying classification.

arguments.claim: After expiry of a reasonable period post-reorganisation, failure to adapt the law means historical considerations justifying classification disappear.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that after expiry of a reasonable period during which the State has the opportunity of making necessary adaptations ,so as to make the Act applicable to the entirety of the new State, if the State fails to adapt the law, historical considerations which initially justified the classification must be deemed to have disappeared.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nuation of the levy of the agricultural income-tax was unfair and number supported by a reasonable standard, and the State having the requisite inform

arguments.court_reasoning: No definite time-limit; requires enquiry into continued grounds for classification and changed circumstances.

arguments.claim: Article 14 permits proper geographical classification if it bears reasonable and just relation to the object, including for historical reasons.

anchor.surface_text: The State is undoubtedly enjoined by Art. 14 of the Constitution not to deny to any person equal protection of the laws within the territory, but a proper classification bearing a reasonable and just relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute does not on that account become impermissible.

arguments.claim: Geographical classification founded on historical reasons is upheld where application of unequal laws is reasonably justified.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in several cases, that where application of unequal laws is reasonably justified for historical reasons, a geographical classification founded on those historical reasons would be upheld Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1  The State of Madhya Pradesh v. The Gwalior Sugar Co. Ltd. and others 2

arguments.claim: Section 119 of States Reorganisation Act continuing pre-existing laws is not discriminatory as it serves necessity, expediency, and maintains regional character temporarily.

anchor.surface_text: Continuance of the laws of the old region after the reorganisation by s. 119 of the States Reorganisation Act was by itself not discriminatory even though it resulted in differential treatment of persons, objects and transactions in the new State, because it was intended to serve a dual purpose-facilitating the early formation of homogeneous units in the larger interest of the Union, and maintaining even while merging its political identity in the new unit, the distinctive character of each region, till uniformity of laws was secured in those branches in which it was expedient after full enquiry to do so.

arguments.claim: Passage of time may obliterate considerations of necessity and expediency justifying geographical classification.

anchor.surface_text: But by the passage of time, considerations of necessity and expediency would be obliterated, and the grounds which justified classification of geographical regions for historical reasons may cease to be valid. A purely temporary provision which because of compelling forces justified differential treatment

arguments.claim: To establish Article 14 violation, must enquire into overall tax burden across regions, not just presence/absence of agricultural income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: It was necessary for the High Court to investigate whether at the date when the petition was filed, special treatment of the Bhopal region in the matter of levy of agricultural income- tax had a rational basis. That necessitated an enquiry into the structure of tax burden imposed directly or indirectly on or in respect of agricultural land or income from it in the different regions constituting the State.

arguments.claim: Courts presume constitutionality of taxing statutes more readily and uphold if permissible policy shown.

anchor.surface_text: In adjudging reasonableness of classification for the purpose of taxation, the Courts recognise greater freedom in the Legislature and if the statute discloses a permissible policy of taxation, the Courts will uphold it. The Courts undoubtedly lean more readily in favour of the presumption of constitutionality of a taxing statute

arguments.claim: Petition is deficient in particulars to justify Article 14 infringement; mere differential treatment insufficient without showing lack of reasonable basis.

anchor.surface_text: The petition filed by the Company was singularly deficient in furnishing particulars which would justify the plea of infringement of Art. 14 of the Constitution. It cannot be too strongly emphasized that to make out a case of denial of the equal protection of the laws under Art. 14 of the Constitution, a plea of differential treatment is by itself not sufficient.

arguments.claim: Case should be remanded for proper pleadings, affidavits, evidence, and retrial.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order and remand the case for retrial to the High Court. The High Court, will, if the Company so desires, give opportunity to the Company to amend its petition so as to adequately plead its case of infringement of the fundamental right to equal protection of the laws supported by necessary particulars.

holdings.text: a proper classification bearing a reasonable and just relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute does not on that account become impermissible.

anchor.surface_text: The State is undoubtedly enjoined by Art. 14 of the Constitution not to deny to any person equal protection of the laws within the territory, but a proper classification bearing a reasonable and just relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute does not on that account become impermissible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 14 prohibits arbitrary denial of equal protection but permits reasonable classification rationally related to legislative object; applies twin test of intelligible differentia and rational nexus.

holdings.text: where application of unequal laws is reasonably justified for historical reasons, a geographical classification founded on those historical reasons would be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in several cases, that where application of unequal laws is reasonably justified for historical reasons, a geographical classification founded on those historical reasons would be upheld Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1  The State of Madhya Pradesh v. The Gwalior Sugar Co. Ltd. and others 2

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents permitting geographical classification post-reorganisation if historically justified and reasonable.

holdings.text: Continuance of the laws of the old region after the reorganisation by s. 119 of the States Reorganisation Act was by itself not discriminatory even though it resulted in differential treatment of persons, objects and transactions in the new State.

anchor.surface_text: Continuance of the laws of the old region after the reorganisation by s. 119 of the States Reorganisation Act was by itself not discriminatory even though it resulted in differential treatment of persons, objects and transactions in the new State, because it was intended to serve a dual purpose-facilitating the early formation of homogeneous units in the larger interest of the Union, and maintaining even while merging its political identity in the new unit, the distinctive character of each region, till uniformity of laws was secured in those branches in which it was expedient after full enquiry to do so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.119 serves temporary necessity and expediency for smooth transition post-reorganisation, preserving regional laws until uniform adaptation.

holdings.text: by the passage of time, considerations of necessity and expediency would be obliterated, and the grounds which justified classification of geographical regions for historical reasons may cease to be valid.

anchor.surface_text: But by the passage of time, considerations of necessity and expediency would be obliterated, and the grounds which justified classification of geographical regions for historical reasons may cease to be valid. A purely temporary provision which because of compelling forces justified differential treatment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary classifications lose validity if expediency fades; requires factual enquiry into changed circumstances.

holdings.text: It would be impossible to lay down any definite time-limit within which the State had to make necessary adjustments so as to effectuate the equality clause of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the view of the High Court so expressed. It would be impossible to lay down any definite time-limit within which the State had to make necessary adjustments so as to effectuate the equality clause of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No fixed period for adaptation; validity depends on continued rational basis post-enquiry into circumstances.

holdings.text: In adjudging reasonableness of classification for the purpose of taxation, the Courts recognise greater freedom in the Legislature and if the statute discloses a permissible policy of taxation, the Courts will uphold it. The Courts undoubtedly lean more readily in favour of the presumption of constitutionality of a taxing statute.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax laws enjoy wider latitude and presumption of constitutionality unless deliberate discrimination shown.

holdings.text: to make out a case of denial of the equal protection of the laws under Art. 14 of the Constitution, a plea of differential treatment is by itself not sufficient.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires proof of lack of reasonable basis, arbitrariness, and overall impact like tax burden disparity; petition lacks particulars.

holdings.text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order and remand the case for retrial to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order and remand the case for retrial to the High Court. The High Court, will, if the Company so desires, give opportunity to the Company to amend its petition so as to adequately plead its case of infringement of the fundamental right to equal protection of the laws supported by necessary particulars.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inadequate pleadings and evidence by both parties; opportunity for amendment, affidavits, and full trial on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The State is undoubtedly enjoined by Art. 14 of the Constitution not to deny to any person equal protection of the laws within the territory, but a proper classification bearing a reasonable and just relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute does not on that account become impermissible.
We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order and remand the case for retrial to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in several cases, that where application of unequal laws is reasonably justified for historical reasons, a geographical classification founded on those historical reasons would be upheld Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1  The State of Madhya Pradesh v. The Gwalior Sugar Co. Ltd. and others 2
We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order and remand the case for retrial to the High Court.

edges.explanation: h3 on continuance of old laws not discriminatory supports c5 allowing historical geographical classification.

anchor.surface_text: Continuance of the laws of the old region after the reorganisation by s. 119 of the States Reorganisation Act was by itself not discriminatory even though it resulted in differential treatment of persons, objects and transactions in the new State, because it was intended to serve a dual purpose-facilitating the early formation of homogeneous units in the larger interest of the Union, and maintaining even while merging its political identity in the new unit, the distinctive character of each region, till uniformity of laws was secured in those branches in which it was expedient after full enquiry to do so.
We accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the order and remand the case for retrial to the High Court.
